page.title: 11LANDSCAPE IN N.E. LEICS
page.content: The landscape is entirely rural with the farmland being divided into fields bounded by well kept hedges. These hedges are trimmed annually and 'layed' regularly, helping to make the area one of the best hunting regions in the country. Many of the fields are of moderate size and retain the ancient hedgerows, shown by lines of isolated trees in an open field, however some boundaries have been removed for large scale arable cultivation. The main area of woodland is the John O'Gaunt Fox Covert composed of deciduous trees and bushes. Bridle ways and small paths criss-cross the wood in all directions. A disused railway line, overgrown with grass and other vegetation, is an obvious feature running as an embankment and a cutting.
